oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_006 p. 2a
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographs and captions from Miss Edith Scott's Memory Book, started July 1957. Her ancestors included the Scott, Deaderick, Crozier, Ramsey, Anderson and Alexander families. Francis Alexander Ramsey Scott (1827-1909) married Margaretta Frances Deaderick (1833-1909) in 1857. They were the parents of eleven children, including daughter Miss Edith Scott (1878-1971). Caption information appears below in the Full Text field.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Photographs; Scrapbooks; Families; History; Mills;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is my great grandfather's mill, which he built some time after 1815, and was almost opposite the log house, we have just seen. We are looking at the back of the mill. In front runs Broadway, and the mill sat back, perhaps two hundred feet from the road, or street it is now. Up the creek, about a long city block, James Scott, Sr. built a brick house on the west side of the creek, and this side of a big bold spring. In 1825 my grandfather, James Scott, Jr., who carried on the milling business started by his father, brought his bride Eliza Jane Naomi Bane Alexander Ramsey, to this home. On October 12, 1827 their first child (my father) was born. When he was six years old they moved across the road to a house his father built in 1833. When he was eleven years old his father died, and from that time on, he was his mother's stay and comfort and in a short time he was carrying the family and the business of the mill on his young shoulders. But with it all, managed to graduate at the Univ
